title: The Works of Robert Louis Stevenson - Swanston Edition, Vol. 16
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: There are mingled some dismal memories with so many that were joyous. Ofthe fisher-wife, for instance, who had cut her throat at Canty Bay; andof how I ran with the other children to the top of the Quadrant, andbeheld a posse of silent people escorting a cart, and on the cart, boundin a chair, her throat bandaged, and the bandage all bloody--horror!--thefisher-wife herself, who continued thenceforth to hag-ride my thoughts,and even to-day (as I recall the scene) darkens daylight. She was lodgedin the little old gaol in the chief street; but whether or no she diedthere, with a wise terror of the worst, I never inquired.

title: The works of Robert Louis Stevenson;
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: He was proud of his drawing and certainly rendered the significance of natural forms. Among his more important works in oil I may mention Shiphuilding on the Clyde, Borrowdale, Canty Bay, St. Monans, Kirkwall, and London from Shooter's Hill. But his name is more eminently connected with the practice of water-colours.

title: The white cockade =
author: Grant, James
snippet: One day the attention of the garrison was excited  by seeing a large boat put off for the isle, from the little green cove named Canty Bay. The wind was rather high for the expedition ; but the boat bore on bravely, with the white foam flying off her glistening bows on each side ; and as all knew that in fresh weather something of importance  alone could warrant a visit to the Bass, the walls were lined by the soldiers, who were curious to see the party arrive.

title: James Nasmyth, Engineer: An Autobiography
author: Nasmyth, James
snippet: The day was beautiful, and the party was of the choicest. After reaching the little cove of Canty Bay, overlooked by the giganticruins of Tantallon Castle, we were ferried across to the Bass;through a few miles of that capricious sea, the Firth of Forth, near towhere it joins the German Ocean. We were piloted by that fine oldBritish tar, Admiral Malcolm, while the commissariat was superintendedby General Pasley.
